abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings convey an unsatisfactory project
            outcome, unlikely sustainability, and negligible
            institutional development impacts; yet, the Bank performance
            is rated satisfactory, though the Borrower's was
            unsatisfactory. Several lessons are drawn from the project,
            namely, that interventions should be geographically limited,
            i.e., location impacts supervision, and therefore
            implementation. The Bank needs to limit its interventions
            geographically so that adequate supervision (and adequate
            supervision funds) be physically possible, and a substantial
            impact made. Any intervention over a wide spatial
            distribution will challenge the quality of supervision, and
            dilute the impact. The states in the country, being
            responsible for water supply and sanitation (WSS) provision,
            should therefore be the implementing entities for water
            supply and sanitation projects. The federal
            government's role should be limited to monitoring and
            evaluation. In addition, given the local government's
            relationship with the communities, they should be involved
            in implementing community based projects, under the proviso
            of understanding and leveraging communities'
            capabilities. Although the project was not negatively
            impacted by a lack of donor coordination, it is evident that
            other donors are likely to repeat the experiences of this
            Bank funded project. Despite the Bank's efforts, other
            programs have thus far, not incorporated these lessons into
            ongoing activities. It does not help that the recipient
            federal ministries differ depending upon whether the support
            is a credit or a grant, the Federal Government and donors
            need to coordinate their activities so as to ensure more
            effective implementation. Furthermore, lessons also suggest
            encouraging 'self-supervision' by project
            executers, enhancing independent monitoring and evaluation
            capacity, and, focusing on sustainability - not asset
            building. It is recommended to scale-up the
            Government's Small Towns (STWSS) program, based on
            criteria where States are the implementers; geographic space
            is limited in accordance to project design and
            pre-determined capabilities; the Government's
            commitment to sustainable STWSS, is supported by the
            communities in their contribution to costs, not undermining
            through parallel schemes dispensing free WSS services. But
            most importantly, the Federal Government should establish a
            formal mechanism to coordinate the support it is receiving
            from donors in the water sector.
